results.content:
This was a very good course. 

Lots of information was covered in a very efficient manner. After completing the course I'm comfortable using the tools covered in a real project. I would definitely take more courses from this instructor.

I would make a couple of suggestions for future courses though: I would like to see the lectures kept to around 5 minutes. Several of them are 20 minutes and entail correcting his coding errors on the fly. Shorter lectures would keep each lecture more focused on the specific item being taught. 

The code in the GitHub repository was tweaked after the video was done with things like variable names being changed. If you are coding along, as I was, this makes it a little harder to go the GitHub repository to try to figure out why your code is not working. 

Also, it would be helpful if attached to each lecture was a resource file with what the before and after code would look like for that given lecture. The  GitHub repository has only the final code, so if you are trying to debug code that your are  creating as you follow along, it's extra overhead sorting through the additional code from later lectures you have not gotten to yet.

I have taken Max Schwarzmuller's Serverless course which was excellent and very comprehensive. I took this course to fill in some of the gaps that were in Max's course, namely using the serverless npm package and using Kinesis. This course did an excellent job of filling in that information.

response.content: Fred.. the feedback you have provided is quiet insightful. Thanks for being frank and taking the pains to write one. It's feedback like these that help us improve our offerings. Highly appreciated!

results.content: This is my first finished course in Udemy, not only because it is short, but mostly because it is useful. The goal of this course is clearly targeted. It is not trying to give a comprehensive and long course, but very focusing on how to apply serverless architecture to a practical use-case. I hope there will be more courses like this and show more use-cases how to use lambda to glue other services, such as SNS, DynamoDb and S3.
